title: 103_s1683
content: The Sterling Forest and New Jersey Watershed Protection Act of 1993 allows for land acquisition. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire an open space tract of land from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The Commission shall manage the acquired land to enhance protection of watersheds, outdoor recreation, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands. Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994 authorizes appropriations for acquiring land described in section 2 and allows the Secretary of the Interior to transfer funds to the Commission to carry out the Act. The Act may be cited as the "Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994." The Palisades Interstate Park Commission manages 23 parks and historic sites in New York and New Jersey, totaling over 82,000 acres. Sterling Forest, a biologically diverse area on the New Jersey border, spans approximately 17,500 acres and serves as a significant watershed for the state. Over 8 million visitors annually enjoy outdoor recreational opportunities within the Palisades Park System. Sterling Forest is a vital watershed area for New Jersey, providing clean drinking water for 25% of the state. It is also an important outdoor recreational asset in the densely populated northeastern United States, supporting a variety of habitats and rare species. Protecting Sterling Forest would enhance the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and provide increased recreational opportunities. The protection of Sterling Forest through the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will involve minimal Federal funds due to stewardship costs being covered by New York and New Jersey. The nationally significant watershed, outdoor recreational, and wildlife qualities of Sterling Forest, along with the high demand for open space in the Tri-State region, justify a clear Federal interest in acquiring the forest for permanent protection. The protection of Sterling Forest through the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will involve minimal Federal funds due to stewardship costs being covered by New York and New Jersey. There is a clear Federal interest in acquiring the forest for permanent protection, considering its nationally significant watershed, outdoor recreational, and wildlife qualities, as well as the high demand for open space in the Tri-State region. This is an effective investment compared to the costs required to protect drinking water for the region if Sterling Forest is developed. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established to protect the watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources in the region. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, and the management will be done by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "Commission" refers to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, "Reserve" means the Sterling Forest Reserve, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established by the Commission upon acquiring enough lands. The Reserve consists of approximately 17,500 acres as depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Secretary will transfer funds for land acquisition. The Commission must agree to specific terms before receiving federal funds for land acquisition within the Sterling Forest Reserve in New York. These terms include managing acquired lands in accordance with the Act, obtaining owner consent for acquisitions, and conveying fee title to the United States if unable to acquire all lands with federal funds. The Commission must acquire designated lands within the Reserve using Federal funds before acquiring any other lands. Within 30 days of acquisition, they must convey conservation easements to the United States for specific lands. The Commission must acquire designated lands within the Reserve using Federal funds before acquiring any other lands. Easement Lands and Conservation easements on specific lands must be managed to protect their wilderness character and restrict development to be compatible with the protection of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. Funds transferred to the Commission must be matched from non-Federal sources. The Commission will manage lands acquired within the Reserve in accordance with its authorities and the purposes of the Act. A general management plan must be prepared within 3 years for approval by the Secretary. Appropriations are authorized for the Act's implementation, with a limit of $17,500,000 for land acquisition within the Reserve.
